III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was involved in two separate incidents while it was believed
that staff was not following his 1:1 supervision. The first incident
happened outside while youth was outside around a smaller youth
who shot at youth with a foam arrow. Youth was not supposed to
be alone with anyone as youth cannot be trusted. The second
incident occurred in the school when someone called the youth by
the full name in which the teacher allowed this to escalate
resulting in youth breaking a table leg off table and using it as
weapon to attempt to break a window when another youth
stepped in the way. First incident Law Enforcement (LE) was
called, but LE was not called for the second incident. Restraints
were used for the second incident. Staff should have been aware
of youth’s violent and dangerous level of assault and need for 24/7
supervision by a court order.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 23
and March 4, 2024, and reported it was court ordered for
Youth A to have 1:1 staffing while at the facility which the
facility did not provide and Youth A only had one group
therapy session in the 45 days Youth A was at the facility.
Complainant later stated it was not court ordered for Youth A to
have 1:1 staffing but it is what the facility should have been doing
for Youth A.
Director of Admissions was interviewed face to face at the
facility on February 23, 2024. Director of Admission reported
Youth A was placed at the facility through adoption subsidy and
denied 1:1 staffing being court ordered for Youth A. Director of
Admissions stated the facility would not accept a youth into the
program who was court ordered to have 24/7, 1:1 staffing.
Clinical Services Manager was interviewed face to face at the
facility on February 23, 2024. Clinical Services Manager
2

reported Youth A had regular group therapy sessions and
individual therapy sessions. Clinical Services Manager denied
Youth A ever being placed on 1:1 staffing while at the facility.
Clinical Services Manager stated Youth A was at the facility for 45
days.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 23, 2024. Therapist reported meeting with Youth A
once a week for individual therapy and once a week for group
therapy. Therapist described toward the end of Youth A’s stay he
needed more support, so she checked in with Youth A daily.
Therapist stated those check-ins were more informal and not
always documented as a therapy session. Therapist reported
Experiential Manager also met with Youth A for more recreational
programming to help provide a physical release to Youth A.
Therapist reported Youth A did not always agree to meet for
therapy. Therapist reported Parent attended one Family Legacy
(family therapy) session in person. Therapist stated Parent did
not ask for more family therapy sessions or request to come visit
Youth A. Therapist reported Parent was invited to the facility but
did not feel comfortable so declined participating. Therapist stated
Parent did not feel the facility was helpful and declined to meet
during the discharge meeting.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 4, 2024.
Youth A reported he did not have 1:1 staffing while at the facility
and was not aware why he would have needed 1:1 staffing. Youth
A described being “supervised as needed.” Youth A denied
youths ever being unsupervised, but then corrected himself to say
one time when a staff member used the bathroom two or three
youths were left unsupervised. Youth A describe the incident of
being hit by a plastic bow and the incident in the school and stated
there were many staff supervising during both occasions. Youth A
stated he did not follow the rules, but staff tried to enforce the
rules. Youth A reported “barely” ever having therapy. Youth A
stated he would only have therapy if he asked Therapist and
stated he did not ask often. Youth A described Therapist being at
the house often and talking with the other youth in the house.
Youth A stated he saw Parent once on campus and once during a
home pass at Christmas.
Documents Reviewed:
• Referral Report for Youth A dated 11/13/2023: Referral
Source is adoption subsidy, no mention of court ordered
1:1 staffing.
3

• Pre-Admission Report for Youth A: No mention of court
ordered 1:1 staffing.
• Acceptance Report for Youth A: No mention of court
ordered 1:1 staffing.
• Adoption Medical Subsidy Out of Home Treatment Pre-
Authorization letter dated 11/16/23 for Youth A: Letter does
not request, or mention court ordered 1:1 staffing.
• Initial Service Plan for Youth A dated 12/19/2023: No
mention of court ordered 1:1 staffing. From 11/20/23
through 12/19/2023 there were eight group therapy
sessions and seven individual therapy sessions.
• Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary dated
1/11/2023 for Youth A: From 12/20/23 through 01/04/2024
there were four individual therapy sessions and three group
therapy sessions.
• Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Incident Report 169680213 for Youth A: Altercation
between Youth A and another youth during school that led
to Youth A becoming escalated, assaultive, and damaging
property. Incident reports Eagle Village staff being present
and intervening.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedure states, Family Therapists will utilize trauma
informed therapies to provide youth with weekly individual
counseling, weekly group counseling, and be an advocate
for youth within their community.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedure: Supervision of Residents states, Youth
Specialists to youth ratio will not exceed 1:3 in Mental
Health/Behavioral Stabilization Programs. At times, a
youth may be placed on 1:1 Supervision. This decision will
be made by the Family Therapist and approved by the
Director of Residential Services, or on-call administrator
after hours.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there is no documentation
court ordering 1:1 staffing for Youth A. Documentation shows
group therapy and individual therapy taking place at least once a
week while Youth A was placed at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
